Best 10 Coffee Place In San Diego

San Diego is experiencing a wave of new coffee shops, making it easier than ever to mix up your daily caffeine routine.

Over the past few months, a San Francisco coffee empire has entered the scene opening two new shops, several new local roasters have emerged and already established cafes have expanded throughout the county.

Here’s a look at what’s new and hot in the San Diego coffee scene, plus what drink to order and what’s good to eat with your beverage.

Better Buzz Coffee Roaster

This chain of local shops has always been on at the top of the local scene, and with its introduction of a new spot at Fashion Valley and a gorgeous new two-story shop in Hillcrest, it's solidified its spot among San Diego’s best. With more than 20 drink options spanning espresso-based concoctions to inventive signature sips, there's always something new to try at any one of its eight locations. Must-order: Best Drink Ever (available hot or iced), a vanilla-laced Americano On the side:

The food menu varies from location to location, but if available, indulge in a slice of zucchini bread with your beverage. Multiple locations

Coffee Hub & Cafe

Bicycle enthusiasts should feel at home at this Point Loma shop that melds coffee culture with bike culture. Two-wheeled enthusiasts looking for a strong cup of joe will appreciate the abbreviated menu (coffee, espresso, cappuccino, Americano, cortado, macchiato, latte) with the option to customize with flavored syrups. Must-order: The signature salted caramel latte mixed with from-scratch syrup On the side: You can’t go wrong with any of the Bread and Cie pastries. 2907 Shelter Island Dr.; 619-738-1482

The Forum Coffee House

Clairemont doesn't shirk when it comes to the local coffee scene, and this hip shop serves some of the most gorgeous drinks in the county. Along with rose-infused white chocolate mochas, lavender-infused espresso with house chocolate sauces, and a bevy of cold brew concoctions, the shop also offers a diverse selection of teas. Must-order: The Code Black, a single-origin Kenyan cold brew pumped up with nitrogen On the side: The 404 Error will satisfy your savory and sweet cravings. Your choice of sourdough or white bread is topped with cream cheese, apricot preserves, tomato, baby arugula and Genoa salami. 4340 Genesee Ave. #110; 858-384-6020

Moniker Coffee Company

Sip your craft latte in an airy industrial space near Liberty Station that's also home to lifestyle shop, Moniker General, both of which celebrate a one-year anniversary in May 2017. Beans from Copa Vida and local roasters are used in drinks, such as flat whites, cortados, macchiatos, cappuccinos and cold brews. Seating extends into an adjoining patio. Must-order: Salted caramel latte using Copa Vida beans and housemade syrup On the side: On the weekends, look for pastries from local spots like Downtown's Donut Bar. 2860 Sim Rd.; 619-255-8772

Lofty Coffee & Bakery

Centrally based coffee fiends don’t have to travel north to Encinitas or Solana Beach for Lofty Coffee. The Little Italy shop is the fourth location for this local roaster, and, like its sibling cafes, it serves signature cups of single-origin espresso, Aztec mochas and salted caramel lattes with the option to order made-from-scratch pastries baked on-site. Must-order: The uniquely flavored Turkish coffee infused with cardamom and raw sugar On the side: Go early for freshly baked macadamia and peach croissants before they sell out. Multiple locations

Philz Coffee

One of the Bay Area’s most popular roasters has come to South Coast Highway in Encinitas and opened a new spot in La Jolla. Both shops attract java junkies for their specialty drip coffees with hints of toffee, toast, dark chocolate and butterscotch. You can also buy one of 28 varieties of beans to brew at home. Must-order: The Mojito Mint, made with the shop’s specialty cream and sugar mix On the side: The sweet treats from Nutmeg Bakery are tempting, but for something savory, try a toast topped with avocado, ricotta honey and pistachio; hummus and fresh tomato; labneh and za’atar; or almond butter and banana. 1060 South Coast Highway; 760-230-6880 8849 Villa La Jolla Dr. #307; 858-242-5070

Copa Vida

Since opening its first San Diego location in 2015, this Pasadena-based roaster has expanded to four cafes across the city. Coffee-minded people looking for a fix in the Marina District will find an outpost on the ground floor of the First Allied Plaza building. (Two cafe outposts are in Carlsbad and Sorrento Valley.) Wi-Fi is plentiful, encouraging worker bees to bring their laptops to the modern space with warming wood interiors. Must-order: Any single-origin espresso On the side: Don’t pass up on the yogurt parfaits. Multiple locations

Communal Coffee

This chic cafe selling both coffee and flowers has become a fast favorite of the North Park crowd since opening in May 2016. Drinks brewed with San Francisco Sightglass Coffee include Americanos, macchiatos and cortados. And as for plants, you’ll find plenty inside and out that decorate the space and are for sale via the on-site florist. Look for second location housed in a pop-up vintage 1959 Shasta trailer headed to South Park soon. Must-order: The latte flight with sippable servings of plain, lavender honey and vanilla bean lattes On the side: Pastries make a strong showing, but for something filling, try the bacon quiche. 2335 University Ave.; 619-363-7737

WestBean Cafe

What started with a Downtown cafe from a local roaster has blossomed into two more locations, one at Liberty Public Market in 2016 and the other in Bankers Hill. There always seems to be a line of people waiting for cups of vanilla lattes, cold brews and other caffeinated beverages. Must-order: The refreshing Kryponite — a cold brew infused with mint and sweetened with brown sugar On the side: Nosh is limited and ranges from fresh fruit to snack bars. Multiple locations

Refill

This bright, modern Hillcrest coffee shop, which opened in 2016 on Park Boulevard, uses locally roasted Bird Rock Coffee beans for hot coffee, cold-brew on draft and espresso drinks that include a blended treat incorporating Nutella. Order your drink "for here" and you’ll find it served in earthenware mugs that are also available for purchase. Must-order: The Nutella-blended brew mixed with the hazelnut spread, espresso and chocolate On the side: The shop offers yogurt, toasts and salads, but your best bet is one of the fresh crêpes filled with sweet or savory fillings like baked eggplant, feta, tomato and basil. 3752 Park Blvd. #104; 619-677-2242
